hints.content:
Partial products help us multiply larger numbers.

We can break the first factor apart by place value and multiply the parts *in any order* by the parts of the second factor. Then we add those products to get the final product.

[[☃ explanation 1]]

Let's take a look at how Matt broke apart the numbers to multiply.

options.explanation:
$54\times 26$

We can break apart $54$ into $50 + 4$ and break apart $26$ into $20+6$.

[[☃ image 1]]

We can start by multiplying $50\times 20$ , $50\times 6$, $4\times 20$ or $4\times6 $. The order does not matter since we will be adding all the products together.

$\begin{array}{rr}
&\begin{align}
54&\\
\underline{{} \times 26}\end{align}\\
\text{any order}&\left\{\begin{align}
1{,}000\\
300\\
80\\
\underline{{}+24}\end{align}\right.\\
&\begin{align}
1{,}404
\end{align}
\end{array}$
options.showPrompt: Can you show me an example please?

options.alt: A rectangular array split in 4 parts. The top left part has a height of 6 and a base of 50. The top right part has a height of 6 and a base of 4. The bottom left part has a height of 20 and a base of 50. The bottom right part has a height of 20 and a base of 4. The left side of the array is labeled 6 plus 20. The bottom of the array is labeled 50 plus 4.

hints.content:
###Step $1$

$\begin{align}
4\blueE{9}&\\
\underline{{} \times 2\blueE{4}}&\\
\blueE{36}&\quad \blueE{4} \times \blueE{9}
\end{align}$

There are $4$ ones in $24$, and there are $9$ ones in $49$.  Also,
$\blueE4\times\blueE9=\blueE{36}$, so Matt did not make a mistake in step $1$.

###Step $2$

$\begin{align}
\tealE{4}9&\\
\underline{{} \times 2\tealE{4}}&\\
{36}&\quad {4} \times {9}\\
\tealE{160}&\quad \tealE{4} \times \tealE{40}
\end{align}$

There are $4$ ones in $24$, and there are $4$ tens in $49$.  Also,
$\tealE4\times\tealE{40}=\tealE{160}$, so Matt did not make a mistake in step $2$.

###Step $3$

$\begin{align}
4\maroonE{9}&\\
\underline{{} \times \maroonE2{4}}&\\
{36}&\quad {4} \times {9}\\
{160}&\quad {4} \times{40} \\
{\maroonE{180}}&\quad {\maroonE{20}} \times\maroonE{9}
\end{align}$

There are $2$ tens in $24$, and there are $9$ ones in $49$.  Also,
$\maroonE{20}\times\maroonE{9}=\maroonE{180}$, so Matt did not make a mistake in step $3$.

###Step $4$

$\begin{align}
\goldE{4}{9}&\\
\underline{{} \times \goldE{2}{4}}&\\
{36}&\quad {4} \times {9}\\
{160}&\quad {4} \times{40} \\
{{180}}&\quad {20} \times{9} \\
\underline{~~~\goldE{800}}&\quad {\goldE{20}} \times\goldE{40}
\end{align}$

There are $2$ tens in $24$, and there are $4$ tens in $49$.  Also,
$\goldE{20}\times\goldE{40}=\goldE{800}$, so Matt did not make a mistake in step $4$.

###Step $5$

$\begin{align}
49&\\
\underline{{} \times24}&\\
\purpleD{36}&\quad 4 \times 9\\
\purpleD{160}&\quad 4 \times40 \\
\purpleD{180}&\quad 20 \times9 \\
+\underline{~~~\purpleD{800}}&\quad {20} \times{40} \\
\purpleD{1{,}176}
\end{align}$

Matt said that $\purpleD{36 + 160+ 180 + 800}$ equals $1{,}076$, so Matt made a mistake in step $5$.
Matt made a mistake in step $5$.

question.content:
Matt tried to evaluate $49\times24$ using partial products, but he made a mistake.  His work is below.

$\begin{array}{llrr}
&&49 \\
&&\underline{{}\times24} \\
&\blueE{\text{Step 1}}&\blueE{36}& \blueE{4\times9}\\
&\tealE{\text{Step 2}}&\tealE{160}& \tealE{4\times 40}\\
&\maroonE{\text{Step 3}}&\maroonE{180}& \maroonE{20\times 9}\\
&\goldE{\text{Step 4}}&\underline{{}+\goldE{800}}& \goldE{20\times 40}\\
&\purpleE{\text{Step 5}}&\purpleE{1{,}076}&
 \end{array}$

**Find Matt's mistake.**

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.clue:
There are $4$ ones in $24$, and there are $9$ ones in $49$.  Also,
$\blueE4\times\blueE9=\blueE{36}$, so Matt did not make a mistake in step $1$.

There are $4$ ones in $24$, and there are $4$ tens in $49$.  Also,
$\tealE4\times\tealE{40}=\tealE{160}$, so Matt did not make a mistake in step $2$.

There are $2$ tens in $24$, and there are $9$ ones in $49$.  Also,
$\maroonE{20}\times\maroonE{9}=\maroonE{180}$, so Matt did not make a mistake in step $3$.

There are $2$ tens in $24$, and there are $4$ tens in $49$.  Also,
$\goldE{20}\times\goldE{40}=\goldE{800}$, so Matt did not make a mistake in step $4$.
Matt should have regrouped the $17$ tens from the sum of the partial products into $7$ tens and $1$ hundred. So Matt made a mistake in step $4$.
